arch:property.oc:show_val: Locus 15 is the soil below Locus 14 in the bathroom. It is a fine, loose silt with a Munsell of 7.5 YR 5/4 (brown). The most noteworthy features of this locus are the large amounts of pottery and glass. There is also a significant amount of bone, and metal is present but does not compare in quantity to the pottery or glass. This locus appears to be the result of purposeful dumping in the bathroom, as is also the case for the Locus 14, 16, and 17. Apparently, once the bathroom and anteroom were no longer functional, they were closed off (the door leading into the anteroom was blocked  Locus 25), and filled in. The dates for the finds are extremely uniform, and suggest a short period of dumping here. The differentiation between Loci 14, 15, 16, and 17 is primarily made by the architectural divisions created by the two rooms; very little difference can be seen in the actual composition of the loci. With further study by our experts will hopefully give us a fine temporal frame for this event. Locus 15 is therefore phased to Stage 5.

Phase X: Site abandonment after major collapse dating to the Byzantine period from the CE 4th to 5th c. New drainage systems are installed including that associated with the newly built west precinct wall.
Full blockage, robbing out and dumping.
3.84 m north south -by- 2.70 m east west.
